The whole thing about multipath isn't actually that "hard".
As already mentioned in the video, we do not have 1 hydrophone to listen with. We have an array of them, so knowing the direction of the incoming sound is fairly simple.
However, a phase array won't help with all the non-uniformity of the speed of sound in the medium.

And I wouldn't be surprised if the speed of sound also varies with frequency. Just like the speed of an electromagnetic wave isn't constant over the spectrum in most mediums.

Though, I am however curious to if they have hydrophones in the back as well. After all, being a few tens of meters further aft gives a different perspective.

16:21 Multipath can affect any transmission and is determined by the transmission characteristics of the medium as well as the reflection/refraction/transmission characteristics of the surroundings - which is pretty much what was drawn in the diagram but expressed in words. TV and FM transmissions suffer from it and good calbre receivers can be equipped with ways to measure it (so you can choose where to best direct your receiver's antenna) or handle it. It's difficult to handle since you don't already know what the transmission signal is (unlike active sonar) and usually the signal is probably more complicated than that of an active sonar (unless you're listening to a radio clock).
But getting back to FM reception (which is much closer to my heart) you can get devices to insert between the antenna line and your receiver (or even more amazingly, right after your receiver's output) that supposedly can deal with the multipath artefacts. Nowadays of course, with the cheap computing power at everyone's disposal, it's much more interesting to deal with this phenomenon using advanced DSP techniques. I've been meaning to learn more about how radar works. Or specifically, how it worked going back to the 70s or so, since I probably won't find much on newer systems. But there's a wealth of declassified documents about older systems. Both tube and solid state systems. But I wanna know everything from how the microwaves are generated, to how the waveguide assemblies worked and what specific parts of them did. How it made sense of the data that came back. How it dealt with errors or determining what is or isn't an object of significance, etc. I certainly have the resources to learn about it. Like I said, there is a lot of information about old systems out there. It seems like almost a niche interest for some people.

But now that I've seen this video, you've got me wondering some, or more, of the same questions about sonar. Like what frequency or spectrum they use, and why. Or are they able to adjust the frequency and/or range depending on the situataion? Is the signal modulated? What kind of circuit does it use to generate the sound? How does a sonar speaker differ from a speaker for audible sound in air, if at all?

Just like with radar, I'm sure if I did some digging I could find some declassified documents explaining how older sonar systems worked in such in depth detail. It's really just a matter of getting them then getting the motivation to get my rear in gear and go find and read them.

I am a former sonarman on an Arleigh Burke class destroyer, and I must say that this is a very good video when it comes to explaining what I used to do in the Navy as an STG 2 Sonar Supervisor. Yes, lots of math and knowing the "signature" of every single ship and sub that exists (or at least those that we know of), plus all of the biologics and underwater topography (and oceanography).

It does take a lot of mental aptitude to first identify the contact that you're hearing (you need to know the specific frequencies that every vessel emits into the water), and then you need to do the trig to actually figure out where it is in the water (i.e. time and space), and what direction it is moving (and at what relative velocity). And you must do this using only heard frequencies in the water, while also allowing for real-time changes on our part or theirs.

We generally had 3-5 minutes to first identify the contact, and then another 5 minutes to determine where it is (and what speed/heading it was on). By the time that I left the Navy, the buttons on my calculator were worn entirely unreadable (and I bought it brand new when I checked aboard my ship). I did two deployments to the Gulf, plus an INSURV. My ship came in second for the Bloodhound Award after INSURV.

The propagation of waves usually depends on the wavelength. Which means that they bent differently depending on the frequency of the sound. There is also issues with the flow of the water along the boat the placement or your hydrophones and dopplereffect. But all of this is pretty much known physics. It's not super advanced or secret. The issue is you need to compute all of this in real time and figure out how to properly identify things. That part is really challenging. In addion to that you might not always have perfect information about the surrounding water available, so I imagine they do some simulations either on board the sub itself or send results of them to the sub to get most accurate readings. Probably you can also try to use sonar to try and figure out conditions of water around you using multiple reflections.
If you are really fancy you could try to map ship engines you know (they are quite unique you can identify ships using sonar) since you know their profile and listen to them and their reflections to figure out properties of water without needing to map it in any active way.

A lot of the classified stuff is a bit ridiculous imo, as virtually every nation launching military submarines is well aware of how to solve these issues.

The main classified part is in the technology itself and the technical details of how the problem was solved. There is sometimes a difference in knowing how to solve a problem in theory, and being able to put it in practice. And sometimes when there are multiple ways to solve a problem, it can be classified to prevent an enemy from focusing all their resources on countermeasures for that particular thing.

I dealt with this kind of stuff in the USAF, having a security clearance, and the debriefings and I just thought some of it was a bit too restrictive based on the academic knowledge around the globe. But it is understandable, as sometimes it's hard to know just what might help an enemy or potential enemy, and I suppose there are still developing militaries who haven't caught up technologically. And espionage is a huge concern in modern times, with nations like China making huge tech strides from stolen materials. So on that note I don't really mind the restrictive nature of military secrecy.

When I was stationed on the USNS Guantanamo Bay, Cuba we used to drop a sonar down to 11000' giving us the different temperatures in the water. We had a sonar set on the bottom of the Caribbean that we could set to test ships' sonar operator on that particular piece of equipment for a period of 8 hours. In other words, no swapping out operators because they don't all work the same way. These tests went on for up to 3 days so we could test all sonar operators. Also, our shore-based operators would give bearing and range to a target in degrees, minutes, and seconds for a very accurate reading and the had to be within 5' of a target attached to the jackstaff on the bow of the ship (a DDE).
There was one time when the ship had to turn so that it would not encroach into Cuban waters, as the target was disappearing I let CIC know I was losing the target but could see the light on the top of that jackstaff. I was told after the test was done the guys on the ship laughed at my response until the shore-based station told them that I was 1/2" off of the center of the target. That shut them up, and I said I could see the light again then read my reading and they were told I was dead on the target. Someone in CIC learned a fast lesson that day.

On a surface ship we use a Canaduan invention called Variable Depth Sonar which drops down below the thermocline painting a full picture from the surface to the bottom of the ocean.
Tha ship launched bathys are just a thermometer connected to the ship with a thin wire so we know where the temperature changes, thus where sonar can bounce off. Now the tower array does most of those functions. But you could do a whole episode on the "Boom Bouncers" which is a complex hydraulic system that keeps the VDS at a set depth while the ship is bouncing about.

This is not a criticism of your videos, it's more of a compliment to Jane's Combat Simulation games - I-688 Hunter/Killer taught me everything you have mentioned at this point, so far. Also, multipath:

17:50
assuming single contact, and you knowing at least how deep you are (plus how deep the ocean is there, which you usually do as well)
You can literally sort out which pingback took which path based literally on that diagram you drew - you don't know the TIMES of returns, but you CAN know the PROPORTIONS between the times of returns of various paths... it's pythagoras all around. So you collect all the pingbacks, figure out which belongs to which proportion therefore to which path, and... done? Oh and the fact that it's a microphone array, so it's giving you angles as well (which I assume can also be vertical (this is probably a classified bit), not just horizontal), would help. Main thing, though, I think would be the proportions. Based on knowing your depth and ocean depth, you can write out an equation for each trip, and all those equations will contain a single variable - roundtrip time to the target. All other paths are proportional to that, and your (known) depth (for top paths) or that, and your (usually also known) depth under keel (for bottom paths).
...Am I wrong? I don't think I'm wrong.

oh wow, at 19:46 when Destin is explaining convergence zone, it reminded me how similar it is to earthquakes detection. Earthquake body waves (that travel inside the "body" of Earth) is similar to sonar waves (also travels inside the body of water) in that both have some zones that cannot be detected.
For example, a P wave can only be detected by the seismograph on the first circle, but the seismographs on the second circle can find waves like PP wave (a P wave that bends as it travels inside mantle until it reaches the surface, refracts into the mantle again, and gets bend until it reach the surface the second time).

I am typing as I watch this video, it's so cool that even shadow zone is also a term used in geophysics! Increasing temperature and pressure profile and the property of the outer core created the shadow zone for Earth's earthquakes. The liquid outer core contribute by stopping S wave (shear wave) to travel through it and refracting P waves as they enter and leaves outer core.

XBT's are not the only way to get the sound velocity profile. In NOAA we use a few other devices that are called CTD's that give us a bit more accurate. There are also a few other options too. This video is fun to watch how other people use sonars.

This is called the shadow zone. It is a favored depth for submarines to operate at for just this very reason. The optimum depth to operate at, called best depth (BD), is a function of the layer depth. The best depth can be calculated from:

BD = 17sqrt(LD) if LD < 60m
BD = LD+60m if LD > 60m

The depth of maximum sound velocity which ocurs on the layer is called the layer depth (LD).

issue is though that the Best Depth calculations aren't exactly 'secret' either, and can be found online at the Federation of American Scientists or in a basic sonar physics manual if you've had to deal with underwater sonar at a program level you have to know it because it can interfer with depth sounding, but the calculations change based on depth Best Depth = 17SQRTLayer Depth if the depth is less then 60 meters else it's LD + 60m.

Really love your series - I was ET in Navy... officially trained Radar, Coms and microelectronics but worked on ASW training facility as staff for a while - helped sonar tech (that just swap boards) and operators repair many systems for our aging sonar systems - sure hope they have made improvements since then - I had to reverse engineer many HP systems to rebuild with modern components... anyhow - even old systems have a lot of classified intel - but what amazes me is how many sounds and profiles the USN has on just about everything that has ever been made known to man and how quickly they can identify just about everything on planet earth by acoustic signatures from ambient passive and active sources.

fun fact, those initial three "bird calls" signatures actually have a shape that immediately sticks out to me as a bat call. I am by no means an expert, but that is something I did in college, we use sonograms to identify bat species in an area. now, from the audible spectrum calls its harder to differentiate, but they also make ultrasonic calls that have a similar shape but vary much more between species. As a former US Navy Sonar Technician, I truly enjoyed being a sonar operator, maintenance technician, supervisor, and even instructor. Each role was incredibly rewarding. I truly feel for this chief, as he has formulate his answers based on multiple criteria: Simplicity, effectiveness, and sensitivity. He needs to simplify otherwise abstract concepts. He needs to make sure he effectively answers the question, even when the question itself is loaded with inaccuracies. Lastly, he needs to ensure he doesn't divulge any sensitive, privileged, or classified information.

By the time he reaches the rank of Chief Petty Officer, he likely has the experience to do most of this; however, it's still a difficult task - especially when the level of sensitivity may change from one moment to the next.

They did a good job, all things considered. I've had to do this myself, and I truly dreaded it. That's why I feel for the Chief in the video. It's not an altogether enjoyable task to answer civilian questions when a) most of the answers are multilayered, b) most of the answers are very abstract to the layman, and c) much of how the US Navy uses SONAR is classified.

I knew of the Underwater Sound Channel.  Years ago, I found this video lecture on YouTube that explored the Roswell 1947 incident but from a non-conspiratorial way where the lecturer explained that Maurice Ewing found out about a depth range where the temperature allowed a sound to travel a long distance w/o losing much signal strength.  The lecturer went on that because of this discovery, the USAF during WWII had pilots carry orbs onboard their fighter planes to throw overboard because they had a crush depth in the underwater sound channel.  Maurice Ewing also discovered an upper atmospheric sound channel at a certain height in the sky.  This led the US Army to listen for Soviet nuclear weapons tests with Operation Mogul.

not just submarine, modern anti-ship missile has onboard library of various radar signatures to differentiate ship by classes/types.

On the multi-path, you can probably ping multiple times and simply get the baseline for the seafloor (assuming also that the topology/map of the ocean is a given and you know your position you can pinpoint the configuration below and take your depth) below and ice above (which is harder than the seafloor because it changes more than the seafloor and there really is no mapping reliable enough but you can still get the depth of the sub and therefore the relative time it would take for a ping striking the ice at an angle). Those two are more predictable. I would also assume that the ping is not singular. You then factor in that the object you are tracking is in motion (while the sub is the one in motion relative to the static solid ice above and the seafloor below). So the best way is to take multiple samples with these things in consideration and subtract the more static pings that come back.

They most likely can't go deep on the frequency discussion because opposing forces can make use of that to derive the range and how those ranges are interpreted. You can then design countermeasures to mimic similar objects emitting what is identified to be non-threats by their algorithm/standards. You can then basically pasa thru at least one defense layer (but there will be countermeasures for that countermeasures so better safe than sorry), among many layers.

If you haven't yet, you should read Tom Clancy's The Hunt For Red October -- there's a surprising amount of info about sonar in that book,. Particularly passive sonar, which they have to use to track down the fictional (we hope) Red October, a Soviet submarine that has a nearly-silent propulsion system. Another book of his, Red Storm Rising, also features info on sonar and submarine tactics, and general Naval tactics as well. Both books are technically fiction, but Tom Clancy always did amazing amounts of research and incorporated a whole lot of truth into his fiction (he was very much like James Michener that way). They're both good books, if you haven't read them.

Hi Destin! I absolutely love your channel! Amazing work, you are the best! I have one question on this specific video. You mentioned that a sub may be able to hide in one specific "blind" spot, and other vessels would not be able to find it with active sonar. This is due to specific conditions affecting the reflection and propagation properties of the water that could create this specific patterns with blind spots. Is this not only true if the "searcher" remains at one location? If the "searcher" changes its location, surely the propagation and reflection patterns of the sonar waves would also change, and consequently the "blind spot" location? The sonar (sound) waves will bend at different angles for different frequencies, thus effectively eliminating blind spots. And with modern day fast processing equipment I am sure they are capable of using a very wide range of frequencies these days. And that is how they would also eliminate sea floor and ice reflections. 16:30 The multi-pathing part of this conversation features in video games such as Cold Waters. Even the density of the water can bend the sonar pulse. The sonar equipment is capable of ray-tracing the curved paths, bottom bounce and more. For example, the thermocline will both bend and deflect the sonar signal, depending on the specific angle of incidence, the severity of the thermocline, the salinity of the water and MUCH more. To say this is complicated would be like saying card counting is more advanced than teaching a child to count grapes. They both involve counting, but card counting is far more complicated and requires you to keep track of multiple variables in order to maintain accuracy. The same is true for SONAR.

Destin, I just wanted to thank you for making this video. My grandpa was a Commander in the US Navy and was heavily involved in testing sonar under the ice caps after WWII and into the Cold War. I was always so curious about what he worked on that was so top secret he could never tell us what he did. All we knew was that it must have been important because in 1999, on a bike tour around the world, he opted out of the portion in Russia because he feared there would still be people after his research. He passed away several years ago, but this video has brought me closer to understanding what my grandpa worked on. So thank you for teaching me more about my family!

P.S. One story he could tell us was about when he was being chased by a polar bear while carrying 50lbs of sonar equipment. He went back the next day to measure his footsteps and each one was between 12-15 feet apart!

He SHOULD have watched 'The Hunt for Red October' again before making this clip ... OR played one of the multitude of submarine sim games available. ACTIVE sonar is rarely used by submarines EXCEPT for NAVIGATION, or for some weapon targeting scenarios. The problem with ACTIVE sonar is that you're telling your targets where YOU are BEFORE you get the return echo to find where THEY are, giving THEM time to fire an active homing torpedo at YOU before you can fire one at them.

Dean Bumpus from Woods Hole (the guy that studied the gulfstreams) was one of the inventors of the bathythermograph. The first sub with an onboard version was the U.S.S. Batfish in 1943 and became one of the first testbeds of the theory of thermoclines in submarine warfare. Once proven, the theory was used by the submarine fleet during WW2 with great results.

Coincidentally, the Batfish is still in existance as a museum ship located in Oklahoma today.

You could use your depth, knowledge of the seabed, and knowledge of the propagation speed to filter out soundwaves off the sea floor / ice sheet above you. You should know your depth accurately since you can just measure the water pressure, but the distance to the sea floor would be problematic if you don't know exactly where you are (since you don't have GPS accuracy after some time underwater). You also would probably modulate the frequency to eliminate other sources of multi-return path signals and to not mistake multiple pings off the same target if the target is moving

this is interesting its kinda seismic reflection Geophysics 101. All that stuff about "multipath" is what geophyscists call multiples and can be caused by the same things garrett is talking about here (seafloor, ice bottom, sea surface) but also rocks of different velocities within the earth.

As an example reflections off the sea surface is what we geophyscists would call a "ghost" and there are some really cool ways to get rid of that from where you position your hydrophones relative to each other to different software processing.

"Plongeur" - (flinches at the hard G used in the video). That one uses a soft French G (often gets approximated with "zh" in English transliteration - unlike the soft English G, there is no "d" sound preceding the "zh" because you don't place the tongue on your upper palate and release it at the start of the consonant - rather the tongue doesn't move). As someone else mentioned, it literally just means "diver" (it's the root of the verb "to dive" (plonger, so plong-) with an suffix added at the end that turns it into a person/thing that does the action (-eur)... one who dives).

Just a quick question on the "straight lines" bit, doesn't it strictly speaking mean that the contact is staying in the same relative direction to you, rather than "it's coming right at you" or "being on a collision course"? Like for example if the sub and a surface vessel are moving in a formation, going the same direction at the same velocity, the surface vessel would stay in the same relative bearing from the sub's point of view, causing a straight line. With the bearing graph alone you can't tell whether a contact that's drawing a straight line is coming towards you, going away from you, or staying still relative to you, just that it's always in the same direction.

Of course they have other ways of figuring out whether the contact is coming closer or not, so this is really a technicality.

As the video correctly points out, with Sonar you not only have issues with multiplies (multipaths) from the sea surface and seabed (depending on depth), you also have distortions within the water column itself causing wavefront bending/refraction and reflection due to differences in sound velocity in the water column based on temperature, pressure, and salinity. This can be used to your benefit if you are a hiding or prowling submarine. This is called the shadow zone here, but is better termed the SOFAR Channel (Sound Fixing and Ranging). Basically, it is located at the bottom of the thermocline where pressure dominates sound velocity increase instead of temperature. It is easily calculated and measured routinely. XBTs (expendable bathythermographs) are still used commercially, for research, and for military use but are limited to when you don't want to come all stop to take a sound velocity profile (SVP). Otherwise we use SVPs which you can lower down through the thermocline and recover and use over and over. This method is time-consuming when in very deep water, but common industry practice. Taking regular SVPs is critical for accurately imaging the seabed, sea ice in this case, bearing and range to targets, etc. It is a standard practice in any hydrographic or geophysical survey as well as subsea tracking which requires a USBL tracking system.
It should be noted that the SOFAR channel not only is used to hide by submarines but also to communicate very long distances over very low frequencies without being directly detected from the surface.

Destin, I really hope you see this. I think speech science can help give insight into your question at 18:05 - at least part of it. Our speech sounds are formed by the manipulation of the sounds coming from our vocal folds. Back in undergrad (current grad to become an SLP), when I was studying formants in speech, I could guess fairly accurately which speech sounds were being made just by looking at a spectrogram. Certain speech sounds have unique ways in which they bend formants. Therefore, the placement of our articulators (tongue, lips) relative to place of articulation (teeth, roof of mouth) alters the raw sound produced by our vocal folds, making speech.

I'm guessing that ice, sediment, rock, organic material - you know, stuff the earth had before submarines - alter the formants of the ping in an already-identified way. People onboard the ship can tell they are looking at something natural from the shape of the formants. Maybe even limestone, shale, sediment, sandstone, etc all can be identified in a flash.

Assuming I'm right, then naturally, steel, aluminum, rubber, plastic - you know, boat stuff - would have their own signature.

*Therefore*, when a sound bounces back that resembles ice + hull of a boat + ice, then they can surmise that that sound hit the ice, then the object, then the ice, then the sub. But if the reflection back from their ping ONLY resembles the formant shifts typical of boat hulls, then you should head in the direction of that individual source of reflection to track the object.

Orrrr not just a guess.

On spectrogram single object would reflect sound in its special characteristics so sounds coming back directly from it would characterize similarly. Well im not sure if human ear can hear a difference but you can check it by hearing to the echoes in the real world. Maybe a reasoneable comparison to start up would be comparing different mountains echoes to different ships echoes. If it is about the different returns coming from a single ping, I dont see this as real problem. In 3 dimensional space waves energy decreases ~r^2 to the source distance. So if the sound return is direct it most likely would be orders of magnitude stronger than indirect ones. Notice that figuring out which echo came first and from which object when you see object in a straight line is only hard on the small distances.

A few seconds later, the example showed the sub as static with the target circling it. I suppose both heuristics make sense, but it was like the difference between reading the book and watching the movie. The second time I paused the video to think about the geometry of sonar was right around the 18:00 mark... Then the answer was classified, dangit. My theory is that the sub knows it's depth from the pressure of the water column above it, and it knows how far it is from the bottom since I would imagine that most of the ocean floor's topology is well mapped, presumably with a resolution that's within the sub's "navigational tolerances" (if that's a thing... what I mean is that the difference between where the sub and the target thinks they are, and where they actually are, is good enough). I would imagine that active sonar might work in conjunction with other navigation tools to account for (or model) the surface interfaces surrounding the vessel to "omit" the known "false readings".

Destin, this was a fantastic rundown on the principles and challenges of running a sonar system. I'm an electronics technician and operator working for a subsea robotics manufacturer, and I can honestly say that the level of depth (pun intended) that you went into was impressive.

Just a quick addendum regarding the characterization of the sound velocity profile: In commercial industry, when you're about to perform a sonar survey of an area, rather than using an expendable bathythermograph, you will conduct a 'CTD cast' using a device commonly referred to as a CTD. They're generally not expendable, and will usually be lowered via a line over the side of the vessel to the bottom, or carried to the bottom by either an autonomous or remotely operated vehicle (AUV or ROV), either way they're typically recovered (so that the data can be collected) and reused.
The name is an initialism for Conductivity, Temperature, and Depth as these are the main characteristics the device measures (many have additional instruments, such as an SV probe, for directly measuring sound velocity). Conductivity tells you the salinity of the water which allows you to produce a curve characterizing the halocline, a higher salinity usually means a higher density and therefore higher sound speeds. Temperature is measured the same as the bathythermograph to characterize the thermocline, just as you explained in the video, and depth is measured via a pressure transducer allowing you to chart halocline and thermocline against the water column. With this information, along with the known depth of the operating sonar, you can compensate for the distortion that a variable speed of sound will have on your imagery.

Awesome episode. This also shows the levels of security and classification. They are only allowed to SAY (in the field) a certain amount, but there are other levels of what may be published officially or legally elsewhere, and other levels of what you can learn or find out on your own, and other levels of what you can actually broadcast publicly as a 3rd party, and other levels of what's actually real.

The military prefers to under-report all their capabilities, so others don't know where the leading or competitive edge really is. Hopefully, your potential adversaries never understand just how good you are, so they don't start trying to get even better. Getting them to underestimate you leads to maintaining the greatest advantage.

All these levels can intermix. A lot of the difference can be whether you are discussing their particular applications and equipment, or are you taking a class on signal/waveform processing in the abstract at a university, or are you using similar phenomena in another setting.

For example, when I used to do sound setup/design, I could walk into a room, see where the speakers were positioned and pointing, look at the shape of the room and its various contents (including ceiling beams, etc) and tell you where the dead spots or hot spots were going to be for various pitch ranges. I might then move or turn one set of speakers even a few inches and greatly clean up the acoustics for the whole audience, or find a best compromise around the space. This is similar to what the sub does.

[At one church I was helping with their sound, I actually told some of the elderly members they needed to avoid sitting in a few certain seats, because their hearing range loss was making dead spots for them in a room, in parts of vocal ranges that were otherwise tuned fine for the general audience. They had a personal "shadow zone" if they sat in those particular spots. One little lady didn't believe me, so I actually had to lead her around to show her the differences while the pastor did some practice lines from the podium for us.]

So I could talk about the way a band will sound all day with no problem, but the minute I start describing it in terms of military equipment and situations, it can suddenly become a classification issue. That's part of why there was some debate and negotiation between the officers about what made which parts of the conversation "a no-go" depending on their interpretation of those levels.

So many funny (or tragic) stories can come out of waveform interactions! After decades of research, it was finally concluded that these kinds of anomalies were found to not only being responsible for the Titanic not seeing the ice berg in time, but caused other ships in the area to not see them or recognize that they were even looking at the Titanic on their horizon to come help survivors sooner.

I think another interesting thing is that the shadow zone is also going to be dependent on the observers' position to some degree. This is similar to fiber optics refraction for instance, where the angle of the wave is very important and determine how much it bends. Only here, it's much more complicated, because the refraction border is not discrete, but rather continuous depending on the water factors Destin mentioned. Thus, I'm pretty sure there's no "absolute shadow zone" where it's impossible to be seen, but rather that it's a game of probabilities that constantly needs to be updated, based on water factors and the detection of other vessels or the probability of all these factors. Multipath is a major issue in case of Radio Signals too. There is a term called "impulse response of the system" which basically says what is the behaviour of the System(ocean channel, simple air channel etc). Ideally, an impulse is sent out and the receiver reads signal along with all the multipath components. This received signal is basically the Impulse response of the System.

So the classified stuff sounds like noise cancelling technology to make the sub invisible. Basically you listen to the sounds that will bounce off your sub towards a certain bearing, cancel those sounds the moment they bounce, then send a replica of what you passively hear from the opposite bearing to the bearing you want to be invisible from.

Obvious stuff, really. They are probably working on detecting the increased water pressure from this noise cancelling tech tho, just in case the enemy has the tech too.

no.

As good an interesting as this video is, I actually pretty much knew most of this stuff. I've played realistic sub sims before and passive sonar is an important part of it. Subs typically tow an extra sonar receiver well behind the ship giving them two places to receive sonar readings from. Because of their displacement, sonar contacts will have slightly different bearings from the front and towed hydrophones, which help you to pinpoint a range on a contact. Learning to identify other vessels from their sound, and doing TMA (target motion analysis) is the next step, to figure out where a target is, what it is, and where it's going and at what speed. With this information one can get a firing solution for a torpedo, all without using an active ping.

Even dealing with thermal layers was part of the simulation. Things that were in different thermal layers could often be hard to detect. If you change your depth such that you cross a thermocline, it can take awhile for the towed array to catch up and the signal returns between them can be different.

Look at a Ham SDR radio ad you will see what a sound waterfall looks like.   Every ship built has a specific sound signature.   Every class of ship, will have the same sound signature.    So a Siera Class Russian submarine has distinct sound signature that can be recognized on a waterfall.  Sonar Techs are taught to recognize ships sound signatures when seen to be able to classify targets at long range as friend or foe.   This is done by listening in the water, through under ground cables or sonar buoys dropped into the water.   A submarine will have an array of hearing devices on it, whereas Surface ships rely on buoy's in the water.

When you ask whether you're allowed to drink the ballast water:
Mr. Evans: "That information has been banished to the shadow zone."

The Shadow zone is created by the Thermocline depth in that area.  This is determined by the BT probe drop as you showed.   Thermocline is a steep temperature gradient in a body of water, IE: drastic drop in temperature.   Below this depth a submarine can hide and not be heard nor pinged on, as sound waves bounce off of the thermocline layer.  In order for a submarine to hear above that depth, they must rise above the thermocline  This is when they can hear and can be detected.  They do this briefly so as not to be discovered.  If they were to ping above that line, ships would know their location, so they dont generally actively ping except to get a bearing/distance location of their target to make a precise aiming solution for their torpedo.  As a surface ship, if you hear a submarine ping, they have acquired you as their target and will be firing on you.   This is what gives a submarine an advantage over surface ships.

Speaking of the Nautilus, have you heard of a whaleback freighter? At the end of the 19th century, a Scottish immigrant named Alexander McDougall was inspired by the fictional Nautilus and its ability to sail undisturbed beneath bad weather. He came up with a new design of ship which would allow waves to wash over and stabilize it. Similar to the book, the whalebacks were black painted iron, looking like a surfaced whale, with turrets fore and aft for navigation and running lights. Narrow hatches and (supposedly) a max size limit around 360 feet made them obsolete by the 1920s or so, but fast for their time.

The shadow zone isn't as spooky as you think.
Since reflection and refraction are influenced by the frequency of the wave, they can send out signals of different frequencies which are each affected differently and produce shadow zones at different depths.
They would then get filtered returns from these spectra.
Also, not all of the impulse is refracted/reflected, since it is not a completely point source or monotonal frequency, as well as variations in the media, there is always some variation in the wave form and some leakage into the shadow zone.
By increasing the amplitude they can get a stronger return from the shadow zone and filter this return and focus on it using gain, fast time control and short time control.

And, Destin didn't even touch the subject of towed sonar arrays which can be miles long.  Those can give much larger base lines, increase the distance sonar can see, increase the resolution, in addition to helping to resolve some of the multi-path problems.  They are designed to keep the array's sensors away from tow vessel noise to improve its signal-to-noise ratio and its ability to detect and track faint contacts like quiet nuclear- and diesel-powered submarines and seismic signals.  Also, a sub can position the towed array above or below a thermal line while the sub stays on the other side.  This was all described in Tom Clancy's "Hunt for Red October" published 1984 (36 years ago!) and in several of his newer books.

And I'm surprised Destin doesn't know more about sonar. No "passive-sonar" isn't SONAR but active and passive both use the same physical phase arrays for their data collection. The principles of phased-arrays are the same for all applications - all WiFi and LTE et. al. use it as well.
The hydrophones can be anywhere as-long-as you know their precise offsets; this is an engineering exercise in cost-optimization between number of recorders and accuracy of the system. The math is simpler if they are uniformly spaced.
The computers are entirely capable of creating spatial plots; bearing-rate graphs are shown purely because some admiral demanded the archaic format.

You can get echoes off 'thermals' not just the ocean floor - oh he talks about that it's in the manual.
The phase-array allows you to detect the direction of the return which you can use to reject, or at least flag, a possible multipath return.

You know the auto-tune plague that descended upon us in recent decades? A geologist wrote an open-source plug-in for Sound Forge. The same type of algorithm would be used in the sonar processing. They both use the "inverse-auto-tune" algorithm - they know the frequency sent out so they inverse-auto-tune the return. The correction required tells you about the material it passed thru.

I had never considered it before seeing this video, but there are apparently a lot of concepts and practices of radio propagation in the atmosphere that mirror what goes on in sound propagation in the oceans.  One thing that came to mind is the similarity of sonar bottom returns to the so-called altitude ring that showed up on PPI displays on airborne weather radar back in the days of high powered radar and parabolic antennas.  Even though the purpose of the antenna dish was to tightly focus the radar waves into a "pencil" beam, so much radio energy leaked off the edges of the dish that radar waves traveling straight down bounced off the ground and returned to the receiver by the same path.  This resulted in a circle, or ring, showing around the origin point on the radar display.  The higher the aircraft was above the terrain, the larger the circle.  Modern radar with flat-plate antennas and digital signal processing do not have this characteristic.

I'm in no way well versed enough in this to be correct. But, it seems like one way they could mitigate the issues with multiple returns is to cross-reference the the times of the returns with the angles they would create, relative to the SONAR emission.
In essence, catalogue the time of the returns from the floor to the emitter and the ice to the emitter. Then, catalogue the time for returns on possible contacts. Using that data, you could rule out the incorrect returns fairly reliably as the up/down returns would help timing the "ricochet" of the sound from the surfaces to the contact, and from the contact back to the emitter. If the angles don't match, then the return was an echo. That was likely incomprehensible, as I am not always great at explaining my thoughts.

Really great explanation about signatures and freq content. The simplified explanation incl. a practical example is very effective - takes the concept totally out of the math of time/space/freq domain. Excellent.

Most of this also relates to seismic data acquisition - something I’ve worked with in the past.

A typical seismic vessel will have a dozen streamers trailing behind it ten kilometres in length and spread out to give a kilometre between each streamer. Each streamer will have a cluster of hydrophones every couple of metres listening to reflections from the gun array behind the vessel. Every change in material within the earth’s crust will generate a different type of reflection, and sound waves will travel through different types of rock at different speeds.

The signals being recorded will contain direct reflections off the surface, reflections off the seabed, reflections from the seabed via the surface, and so on. A lot of the initial signal processing goes to cleaning up those reflections, but not entirely - they still contribute to the overall picture by allowing you to see around corners (for want of a better analogy).

When surveying an area of the seabed, the vessel will sail back and forth over the area with the gun array firing once every five or six seconds which allows a really accurate 3D map of the earth’s crust to be created.

Knowing that Dustin has a background in missiles, the first few minutes were brutal to watch as he did not make the analogy of Active Sonar to Radar and Passive Sonar to Electronic Warfare. The sound velocity profile part was well done, but there was no mention that the submarines are hunted in the shadow zones by passive arrays seeded from the air, and relayed back to the ship, if not actively hunted by the helicopter or aircraft. Something not covered in this video: the sound used for pings. In order to help differentiate time-shifted echoes, the ping is not a pure tone but a collection of varying tones designed to never evenly superimpose on itself. The sound channels Destin describes bending sound waves in the ocean happen in the air as well. Where I grew up, on some nights, just after sundown, you could hear the distant rail trains. It was much later in life that I learned this is because the cool, humid air of early dusk can sometimes form a sound channel in the air, which bends the sounds of those distant trains so they could be heard miles away.
If you've ever heard that sound of ghost-like trains just after sundown, but not at other times, it's probably due to this effect.

12:31 "Their bearing rate will remain constant" well yes!It's exactly 0,the bearing rate is 0 if the bearing remains constant.
Constant bearing rate though could mean a change in bearing that is constant e.g. +20 bearing every minute,so yes it is constant but it's more specifically 0 if the bearing is not changing with time.
Any straight line in that graph is constant bearing rate,but any line perpendicular to the bearing axis is specifically 0 bearing rate.Any straight line that has an angle with the bearing axis,has constant non-zero bearing rate.

If anyone wants to play with sonar themselves, I highly recommend picking up the game Dangerous Waters. It's a simulator of several classes of submarine, one class of destroyer (i.e. - submarine hunter), one type of helicopter (also a submarine hunter, linked to and deployed from a destroyer), and a land-deployed sub-hunting airplane. It has rather detailed (as much as can be) sonar stations where YOU listen and watch and classify sounds. Quite fun. ... Very slow paced game with sudden bursts of action tho, which isn't really to some people's taste in gameplay.
WW2 sub sims are also fun, but THAT sonar is extremely primitive compared to today. It's entirely up to the sonar operator to classify contacts and determine what direction they are and estimate distance. Then in the con room other people will use Target Motion Analysis (TMA) to try to pinpoint where the target is, how far away, and how fast it's moving. ... TMA is still done on modern ships, but is done with computers rather than by hand on navigation maps. (Tho it's my understanding that crew on modern subs are still required to learn the by-hand method)

As a prior STS and a former sailor on-board the U.S.S. Toledo it was nice to see the ole girl again.

As a side note when talking about sound speed we use the acronym TSP to remember teaspoon i.e. temperature, salinity and pressure. If you look at pg 207 of RP-33 you see the values of 6ft/sec for 1 degree of temp, 4.7ft/sec for 1ppt change in salinity and 1.7ft/sec for every 100ft depth(pressure). Temp is the largest variable followed by salinity. Pressure however is a constant that will always equal 1.7ft/sec for every 100ft of change.

Overall for those not familiar with how SONAR operates, great job. There are few instances of needed clarity regarding sound speed profiles and line of sight illustrations.

Hope you enjoyed your on the 769.

Wow, that's awesome. The first part I especially enjoyed b/c I'm working with some audio signal processing right now and after diving in I found out how extremely complex it is to create that spectrogram from scratch looking at the raw data. Think of it like looking at all the objects in your living room and then try to figure out what % of the illumination of that object you're seeing from your perspective is from which light source. In theory it's easy because there's only 1 main light in the room, but the isolation I've found to be very difficult since there's light (or in this case noise) always trickling from other sources. It's absolutely amazing what our ears can pull apart in terms of parsing this data in real time.
.
Back to the sub though, really interesting. I'm curious how much of the classified stuff is "common sense" to other sonar engineers in other 1st world military powers like Russia and China. I'm curious if it boils down to a "everybody knows but nobody says" situation, or if it's like a "our sonar works better than theirs" type situation.

OK first off, how SONAR works is not classified. Every Navy around the world has it on their subs and surface ships and it all works pretty much the same way. However, how the SONAR works in conjunction with weapons systems is. If they told you otherwise, they were pulling your leg. As you found out, most of the information you're looking for is on the internet. One of the really cool things about SONAR, is not only can Sonar Techs (ST) classify a contact by Type (Carrier, Transport, Cruise Liner, Destroyer, etc), but they can even identify the contact down to the specific ship or boat, (USS ENTERPRISE, USNS BOB HOPE, USS VIRGINIA, etc).

My expertise is in photonics, not sonar, but one fundamental feature of sonar that wasn't mentioned must be the return ping's wavefront or phase as a function of wavelength, time and microphone position. In its most simple form you can imagine having two microphones at the front of a sub, one on the left and one on the right.

If a ship you are detecting is somewhere off to the front right, the sound will return to the right side mic first before the left mic. The phase delay from left to right can be used to calculate at what angle the sound is coming from (direction to get to the ship). The distance on the other hand would be calculated from the total delay from initially releasing the ping to receiving the ping back. The acoustic signature details can be used to predict which ship it is, potentially not just the model but possibly the exact specific ship (eg one ship might have slightly lower compression in one cylinder compared to another ship of the same model or perhaps there is a bit of bearing noise in a prop shaft, etc).

One way to calculate how fast an object is moving is to ping it twice and use the two distances to calculate its speed and direction. Another option is to use the doppler effect by releasing a specific frequency and looking at how much it changes. This change in frequency tells you how quickly the ship is moving towards or away from you. By comparing the doppler shift between two or more separated microphones, the direction of travel can be calculated.

@SmarterEveryDay The calculation of the shadow zone or "best depth" isn't too hard. Assume the following: Snellius law says the angle of a ray path between two differing mediums is sin(phi1)/alpha1 = sin (phi2)/alpha2 where phi is the incident angle and alpha the velocity. The point where the sound travels parallel relative to the surface, or critical angle/ shadow zone is therefore phi2 =90° and therefore sin(phi_shadow) = alpha1 / alpha2. Assume the velocity is a function of depth or alpha_d = f(depth) then your "BD" is at f(d0)/sin (phi_shadow) = f(d_shadow)..  where f(d0) is the sound velocity right above the submarine. So this is not only a function of depth but also a function of angle relative to the "contact"

Dr R. M. Michaels at the University of Illinois in the early 60's helped to define the calculus equations to describe the rate of change of rotational angle (relative to the point of view of a moving body) of movement of things as they pass you while moving.  It's fascinating that the Navy took that concept to a whole new level.  Thanks for sharing!

Thing about the shadow zone is that it works both ways. It can be difficult for someone to see you there, but it's equally difficult for you to see anyone else. But all of that depends on the respective distances of the listener and listenee. Basically, the closer the other guy gets, the more likely they are going to pick you up (again this goes both ways). Also, a TA being dragged around below the layer can be at favorable acoustic angles and pick you up anyway, shadow zone or not. Likewise your own TA can detect someone that your spherical cannot.

As a former surface sonar tech, this brought back many memories. The "BDR" is one of the scariest for all surface ships.
But your version of a "ping" is kinda misleading. In truth, it's more like a brief "beep" at a specific frequency (the higher, the better for accuracy). And there will be no decay in it, all would be the same level. The shorter the duration, the better, but there is the "diminishing returns" problem that means there is an ideal ping duration depending of the range being scanned. The only "decay" effect would be the gradual reduction in the loudness of the reflection with distance. The vast number of individual reflection from the surface, the bottom and all other items surrounding you create the reverberation so desirable in music, but bothersome in SONAR. Interpretation of SONAR echoes is as much an art as a science.

Just don't ask them about SQUID.
Spherical QUartz Interfereometer Detector.
Spinning quartz ball that flexes a tiny bit due to local gravity fields.
The flex gets a piezoelectric thing going, which is detected using Josephson junctions, a fantastically sensitive transistor.
It's a navigation system that allows large undersea features like mountains and valleys to be 'seen' without pinging.
It can't produce images, but it can tell the operator that a large something is off to port or how far from the bottom.
Declassified in the 1970's, its exact resolution and sensitivity is still secret.
I guess today's systems can pick out surface targets.
Can't jam or detect a system based on gravity distortions!
See also: acoustic daylight.

@20:54 - Not sure why the equation is redacted (it's not classified) but here it is. In meters; LD is layer depth, BD is best depth.

BD = 17√LD, if LD < 60m
BD = LD + 60m, if LD > 60m

Keep in mind, this just means things on the surface won't be able to hear you. Anything positioned above the layer or operating on the surface using towed array sonar or sonobuoys can still see you, assuming those devices cross the layer. Aircraft, destroyers, other subs, whatever. You're never completely safe. :)

Source: "Principles of Naval Weapons Systems", ISBN 9781591146674. It's also available as a bundle on Amazon, via the DoD, with ~11 more 300+ page technical manuals for something like $30.

What you say at 12:15 is true not only for submarines, but at the most basic level for all ships and boats. If you are on the lookout and spot an object and you are not certain if you are on a collision course with it, you can take the bearing and see if it changes. While the technology on the sub is of course many times more sophisticated, I have been on a vessel where you could literally pop a metal device on your compass, look through it and adjust it until you see your object and then read the bearing from the compass. Then watch how the bearing changes over time and you know where it will pass you and how you could steer to increase the distance between your ship and the other one.

There's alot more information available from public sources. Anything making noise has a loudness inversely proportional to the square of the distance of the observer from it. This means that if you halve the distance, something is 4x louder. Active sonar hits this law twice: The submarine makes a "ping" and the loudness at the target is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the target. Some of that noise gets reflected back, and it too is subject to the inverse square law, the overall effect being that doubling the distance makes active sonar pings 1/16 as loud.

Active sonar is very loud and can be heard a huge distance away, probably thousands of miles, whereas quiet submarines are very hard to hear even when relatively close. So, to avoid detection, submarines use passive sonar as much as possible.

In WWII, Sonar used single-frequency "ping" noises. I suspect that modern active sonar gear uses spread-spectrum, with short pulse lengths, so as to be much less noticeable to anyone using passive sonar, though the ability to do old-style "Ping" noises is probably retained for entertaining journalists!

Anyone wanting to know more than this needs to look at better sources.

Great summary of submarine sonar! One small correction, a vertical line on the passive waterfall display is a zero bearing rate contact. Technically you are correct that it is a constant bearing rate but the fact that the rate is zero is the most important bit of data. The slope of the trace is the bearing rate. You are correct about zero bearing rate contacts being dangerous. We used to use the initials C.B.D.R. , constant bearing decreasing range. That’s a collision course.

In High School physics class we did a demonstration of the monkey gun.  We used a magnetically held "monkey" on a pole using a pneumatic barrel with a switch at the muzzle that releases the "monkey."  The story is that monkeys would hang from a branch, wait for a muzzle blast to let go and fall to avoid being hit.  Question, where to aim to hit the target.  With all the high speed cameras and resources we could see this being tested at different velocities.  You can explain the math and science with this concept making it educational and fun.

The animations were really well done but after hearing the discussion they felt really redundant. It felt like it took three times as long as it should to get to the Shadow Zone and the hydrophones in the GIUK Gap. The declassified information on these signals intelligence topics could make the video a lot more engaging. I realize that would take a lot more effort to research and process but it would raise appreciation for those who in the field. The officers are not allowed to discuss these things and are likely under a ton of scrutiny but you can connect the dots that demonstrate the amazing things publicly available information. The joy of discovery while on the sub must be really amazing but as a viewer our perspective and experience of wonder is very different. One area that would have really helped would be exposure to more Navy jargon so that the animations with simplified explanations in common English would be more beneficial. I remember picking up a lot of what you discussed here just watching Hunt for the Red October in all its flashy Hollywood fizzle.

Another video on the hydrophone and other types of listening stations could be really interesting. You might not even need military to get access to a great setting to explore it. One way to cut down on multipath issues is using special antenna tricks, because each time the signal reflects off something the signal phase gets inverted.
If you have multiple circular polarized antennas (some right hand polarized and some left hand polarized) then you can determine if a signal has reflected an odd or even number of times by looking at which antenna type detected the return signal and which did not. Then you can ignore all signals that have reflected a number of times that indicates they are not the signal you care about.

No one every mentions the smell. Destin, Id love to hear your take on what you think submarines smell like.

Theres a lot of fun smells on subs. Burgers hitting the grill on a Friday, Pizza night, fresh bread on the midwatch. But there's also 132 manly men (and occasionally a few badass women) all living in close quarters. There's sanitary tanks venting, trash room in the scullery, partially thawed and very slowly rotting meat in the semi broke-down freezer midway through your deployment (maybe that was just my boat lol). But really the defining smell, the SUBMARINE smell is that stank that permeates everything you brought onboard with you, and even follows you home after going ashore.

Personally Id say subs smell sorta like a dirty 1995 McDonalds that serves a lot of Fillet-O-Fish and who's fryer is full of high-mileage 90wt about 18 months past due for a change. The primary sub smell comes from monoethanolamine, know as amine on subs and as MEA in the chemistry world. Amine is used in the air purifying equipment onboard as a means of scrubbing C02 from the air. A lot of people say subs smells oily, like machinery or engine oil, and they kinda do but to me the boat smell is a lot more like well used fryer oil. And a lot of other people say the "sub smell" is like cat pee. The cat pee thing sorta jives since MEA gets produced using ammonia, and there are other chemicals used onboard that also have the distinct cat pee smell and could potentially get into the air.

Anyways if you actually read all this Destin, thanks. its a shame that what happens aft of the RC shield was off limits for you and this project and probably will be forever. The nuclear and general engine room stuff would really blow both you and your viewers minds.

Never been on a working submarine, never seen anything classified, but here's how digital cell phones cope with multipath:

Each bit of the signal is sent as a sequence of 128 'chips', and half the chips are flipped (from 1 to 0, or 0 to 1) in a pre-arranged pattern before transmitting. The received signal is also chopped up into chips, and a decoder uses the same pattern at some small delay to flip the amplitude of, again, half of the chips.

The delay is to make up for the signal's time-in-flight. The first half of the trick is that every path has a different length, and therefore a different time-in-flight. When you select a certain delay, you're really selecting a certain path length to listen to. The decoder hunts for the strongest signal path by trying out different delays.

In a perfect radio environment -- one cell tower, one phone, one path, zero noise -- finding the right delay and flipping the chips back would perfectly re-create the original bits: 128 chips in a row that are all ones or all zeroes. In the real world, it creates a statistically recognizable approximation of that: blocks of 128 chips that are skewed toward a higher or lower amplitude than the average.

And there's the second half of the trick. This statistical reconstruction only works for one chip pattern and one path length. That's the only way flipping half the chips is going to drive a large block of them away from the average signal. For everything else -- whether it's a noise burst, another return of your signal along a different path, or even another phone on the exact same frequency but using a different chip pattern -- it drives it towards the average.

That's how the decoder chooses between one delay and another. When the delay matches the time-in-flight of the strongest signal path is when the decoder output looks the most like the original solid blocks of chips.

Even in the 1990s, the integrated circuits in your phone would have three decoders on the same piece of silicon. Two of them could find the strongest signal paths from two different cell towers, and the third would find the second-strongest path from one of them. It gave you soft handoffs from cell to cell and didn't allow a passing bus to block your whole call.

A 1976 Soviet over-the-horizon radar system used a very similar technique of modulated pulses, plus massive antenna arrays that could detect the bearing of each return. They called it Duga, NATO called it Steel Yard, and radio amateurs that it blasted off the air called it the Russian Woodpecker. The first Duga antenna is in the Chornobyl evacuated zone now.

When I worked at Jake Pickle Research Center, it was common knowledge that the folks at Advanced Research Labs on campus were "working on acoustics" for the Navy. On a lunch break I went to ARL to see if I could talk with someone about the program. I was stopped firmly, but politely, and was able to ask one of the principle research guys a question. I told him I had been told that the developments in the program enabled them to hear Russian subs at a range of thousands of miles. The guy said, "With the current technology, we have been able to tell when each crew went to mess. With the new stuff, we can tell if they are having mayonnaise or mustard on their sandwiches."

I have a buddy who was sailing solo around the globe. He told a story about being adrift on a pitch dark night and hearing mechanical sounds somewhere out over the water, but he couldn't see anything. He started worrying that it might be a submarine and wondered if a submarine had ever hit a boat.

I asked the bubbleheads in the office smoking area and received a chorus of "Oh, f* yeah. Happens all the time. Google submarine collision. Wikipedia has a whole list of them. Heck, the Brits hit a mountain underwater, and that thing was on the maps!"

If you google submarine collisions, one thing stands out about all of the boats that have been hit: They've all been underway. They've all been making noise at the time of the collision.

So, next time you find yourself out to sea, keep that life jacket handy.

While active and passive sonar are complex and fascinating, there is another whole area that is a bit more taboo - acoustic deception. You can buy, relatively cheaply, a pair of headphones that not only play music - they will do a pretty amazing job of making you acoustically "blind" to the outside world, injecting a signal in with the music that cancels outside sounds. This is a harder trick to pull off in an open environment - but it is possible to pick one location, say the location of a potentially hostile vessel, and broadcast an acoustic signal that can, in effect, trick the hostile sonar in a variety of ways. It is also possible to deploy relatively inexpensive (compared to the cost of a submarine) devices that can acoustically decoy away a hostile vessel. These measures depend in no small part in intimate knowledge of your opponents' hardware and more importantly, software capabilities and vulnerabilities, so outright espionage plays a part in the acoustic cat and mouse game of military sonar, too.

The multipath issue is something that most car radios get affected by in a city with large buildings. That is why you can have a clean signal one moment and garbage the next. Since you are hearing the radio picking up multiple signals. HD radio and satellite radio get around this by putting a time signature in the data being transmitted. So it does not try to play any data past a few seconds.

Multipath has some filtering with time of arrival and direction. First return is important, due to shortest distance. Direction bearing is different for multipath and changes bearing. Other filtering that can be used is narrow beams, eg 50KHZ and 200KHZ fish finders have different beam width in fish finders. Combined with a few good DSP (digital signal processors) and the known noise can be attenuated, such as in your birds and crickets example. With delay in a DSP a repetitive signal can be actively recognized and masked so the loud bird calls can almost vanish with the crickets and the background train would stand out as a new energy source. A sudden change in the bird call would be flagged as a change. Crickets suddenly going silent would be a marker.

Going to take a shot at what that bleeped out section was: If you're trying to discern which path your signal is coming back from, your best bet will probably be to use specific pulse sequences and then analyzing time-of-flight and doppler shifting of those pulse trains.

If I send out a pulse train with 200 pulses/sec and each has an decreasing temporal length from 1/2000 to 1/2200 sec then my return signals will be shifted in frequency based on the relative speed of the target and I can determine specific paths based on which temporal waveform reaches me first.

Heh. "Challenging" is an understatement. It would be a difficult enough conversation, when you introduce a camera, that's an impossibility. [I'm a little surprised the Navy gave this SDcard back. ;-)] I think it would've gone better if the questions were available in advance so everyone could have plenty of time to think about it and phrase their response within the constraints of security.

The question about "frequencies" took a long time to figure out how to answer... their hydrophones work much like your ears, there are frequencies too low and too high to hear. [they can't say what those limits are, obviously] You don't set out to listen for any specific frequency; our brains just aren't wired for it. The sonar systems work very much like our ears... recording everything within the sensitivity of the hydrophone, and the computers run the data through an FFT (just like the audio program you already used) which pivots the signal from time to frequency so you can see what frequencies are there and at what intensities. Those patterns can be matched to profiles of known sources -- as you previous showed with the crickets and train that our brain would never have noticed without help, once isolated and amplified, our brain instantly recognizes them because we know what those things sound like... they're part of our database. The sounds things make are not monotonic, they're made of a soup of frequencies over a span of time. So looking for an exact frequency wouldn't tell you much -- lots of things generate 4khz, for example.
That sailor is definitely not "trying to avoid leaking classified info". He just doesnt understand the questions.

In geophysics (seismics) we have all of that, too, inside the Earth. Quakes will go into the Earth and bend back up. They are partially reflected on each layer of the Earth and partially transmit deeper. If you look at seismographs of a big quake, you see the signals many times, and, in fact, big quakes travel around the whole Earth so you see them returning again and again.
But from all this data you can compute nice density profiles of the Earth so we can map the inner Earth quite well thanks to all those signals.

How to solve multi-ping problem? Fire a second ping out of the back of the sub (even better on a long tail cable) and register the returns from the ice above and the bottom below, now subtract that data from the ping in front. Apply the graph for speed sound in your condition and calculate the distance from the ice and the bottom, that way you can calculate the angle of reflection from the time of the reflected pings. You've got your bearing.. Probably the solution is easier than that but this is what I've came up with

The passive sonar systems on our subs can hear the mechanical noises emitted by other ships, we can determine what class of ship it is even (sometimes) down to the exact name of the boat. example; The Russian Navy have multiple Akula 1 and 2 class submarines, we can tell the difference in the two by the sounds the machinery makes. the "plant noise" an akula 2 is similar but ultimately different from an Akula 1. you can literally see it in the sonar waterfall displays.

I’m a hydrographer and for one it was great to know something before Dustin showed it. He is not joking about multipath and especially sound velocities in water. Not knowing the speed of sound in water can change your depth measurements on the order of meters in some cases. Now understand that some ships maintain such a deep draft that they clear the bottom by a meter. So you can imaging the problem if sound velocity is not properly measured.

I would guess Passive Sonar has something to do with reading the actual waves inside the water. As sound travels differently at different densities so too does water and as objects move through that water it leaves behind underwater waves, an afterimage of an object. The waves themselves would act as a type of sonar constantly feeding into the sensors in the submarine letting them know the water conditions and if there is anything moving in the water in the same way a shark can smell blood at long distances. As the waves bounce off a rock it sends back a "ping" of sorts that can be read by the submarine, just using the natural motion in the ocean. Instead of sound we also use water and other variables to find objects. (not a part of the military, just an educated guess)

The bending of sonar waves due to different travel velocities of the signal is the same in seismology. Here, the density of the medium (Earth's crust, mantle and core) increases with depth and so does the seismic wave velocity. The profile isn't linear either. Shadow zones also exist, but they are due to the fact that shear waves can't travel through the Earth's liquid outer core.

There wasn't any mention of stereoscopic location (I came up with this term, I'm not sure how it's really called), but at 15:27 before the abrupt cutoff we can see two "eyes" on the side of the submarine. Just like our stereoscopic eyes can gauge the 3D shapes due to the offset of our eyes, with two passive sonars someone could calculate the location of an object by factoring in the phase shift of the same signals between the two sensors. Of course echoes and "optical" bending (all of this density stuff is basically like optics in my mind, just different wave length) makes things a little more complicated than just simple trigonometry, but it's doable. Echoes I think are also not too hard to rule out: the signal will loose fair amount of strength (amplitude) when it bounces off a surface and also have to travel longer so the attenuation will be larger as well. So you'll want to keep the strongest echo back and throw away the weaker ones. Now if you are in such an echo chamber of a cold water layer, that could be tricky, but I think this still holds.

Said it before, Destin will meet and talk with someone who usually has to dumb things down for most people they meet, Then Destin will reference something very specific and you can see the other persons light bulb light up and go "oh you're not a normie, You actualy know things" and they click into high gear and suddenly the talk becomes more in depth.

At 4:20, this is only partially true! Past the ear canal, the cochlea (that snail-shaped organ) has sections of membrane with varying geometry, each of which with a corresponding resonant frequency. Because of this, your ear performs a live Fourier transform in real-time and transmits the frequency amplitudes to the brain with tiny hairs connected to nerve tissue. What we see at this timestamp is the sum signal of these nerve endings.

Not the worst explanation of how sonar works. Not to knock STSC, but a senior sonar watchstander such as an AUX operator would likely answer the system questions better as they are more hands on with it on a daily basis. Also, what you called convergence zones exist, but not in the SVP example you used them with. The SVP you showed would create surface duct or half channel propagation. The SVP you showed for Sound Channel would actually be the same one that exhibits CZ propagation if the proper conditions are met. Also, I know you're being general on purpose, but most submariners can't read/understand those displays. STS, FTs, and officers can, just about everyone else would have as much an understanding of it as you did when you showed up (likely worse). Kinda a bummer you didn't go over basic array design and whatnot, though I'm sure they just wanted to steer clear because you can easily get into classified regions quickly.

Gotta say, and not trying to sound like a hippy here, if we as a species were less worried about how to try to kill our "neighbors" or how to stop our neighbors from killing us, we probably could go a long way in understanding things. I say this because one thing I would teach my students about when talking about something like astronomy is that it's largely not important of "which culture thought of it first" when it came to things like how the planets moved, etc. because of when stuff happened there wasn't much communication between say India and Western Europe or Native Americans, or Aborigial people, etc. and as a result you have many cultures throughout time who effectively had to "reinvent the wheel" which is why we see a lot of "*henge" type structures all over the world, or pyramids (and that doesn't have anything to do with aliens) because these tools were used to do one thing really well and each of these cultures at some point in time figured it out. Now bring us to today, and science is largely shared once it's known... except when that science is how to stay stealthy, or listen for things, or kill people, and once again we have to "reinvent the wheel" and all of that is time and resources that if spent in other avenues could advance us as a species just a little bit more.

I would think the solution to the Nautilus problem would have a lot to do with the Doppler shift of the sound you get back. Multipath is an issue in medical ultrasound as well! Sometimes when we try to image a hollow organ/structure (e.g. bladder, abcess, air spaces), the sound waves bouncing off the floor of the structure can mess with the waves bouncing off the far wall and create artifacts, creating a potential for missing diagnoses. Thankfully we are trained to look out for those and the fix is simple (just jiggle the probe a bit until the artifacts are gone).

Back when I was 14 ish in the middle of summer (reason I mention it's summer is cause all the leaves were blocking my view), I went over my friends house. He just got a new pellet gun. We were in his back yard shooting a target. Then we herd a squirrel making a bunch of racket in the front yard up in a tree (about 150 or so feet away). The idea for high(er) resolution synthetic aperture radar most likely originated from existing sonar technology. (Full disclosure, I was a radar technician in the Navy).

The delineation between regular and SAP radar systems is that SAP takes into account all relative motion - that of the signal source as well as that of targets. That relative motion is then plotted as apparent motion relative to the signal source. The "waterfall charts" you referred to are also known as histograms.

Transceivers (or transducers as they are called in sonar) are both used to generate the pulses AND listen for the return echos. To do this high speed switching between transmitting pulses and listening for the return echo must be used. Therefore timing of digital signal processing is critical. The receiver circuitry is electrically isolated from the transmitted signal by gating the receiver with a blanking signal which is generated in tandem with output pulses.

We humans also generate blanking signals in our visual cortex. They happen during rapid eye movements called secades. During the time our eyes are moving through a secade, our eyes are switched completely off and when the secade ends they are turned back on again. Because of the persistence of our vision we are unaware that our eyes were ever turned off for a brief period of time. Bats also utilize (high frequency) ultrasonic sonar and they too have a blanking circuit for their ears. They switch their ears completely off hundreds of thousands of times per second during each emmited pulse of sound. Fun fact - bats are some of the loudest creatures on earth emitting ultrasound at an astounding 120dbm! They need those high speed perfectly synchronized blanking circuits or they would deafen (and thus blind) themselves!

Interestingly, one of the quirks of radar is minimum range detection. During foggy conditions radar is useless under a minimum distance due to the blanking circuitry which would still have the receiver circuitry electrically isolated from the antenna when the pulse echo returns. As an example, a radar mile - which is the time it takes a ping to be emitted and return from a target that is one mile away (about 12.4 microseconds for a nautical mile and 10.75 microseconds for a statute mile).
