16:45 this is a similar thing with ultrasound imaging in the medical field:
They are called reverbration artefacts. And they happen when sounddense and soundloose tissues are next to each other. Then a way bigger proportion of ultrasound signals are coming back and the ultrasound machine thinks, something else is there.

18:50 again, similar thing in ultrasound imaging:
The main thing, an ultrasound machine is measuring, is the time between sending off the signal and recieving the echo. (and of course the amlitude of the echo). However, as this is just time, the machine needs to know, what the underlying tissue is, to give a good and realistic picture. Or to be exact: it needs to know the soundvelocity of that specific tissue. What that means, is, that ultrasounds have different modes or programs for different organ systems. (for instance. the abdominal setting has a different speed than the cervical or the cardiac settings)

And, with the Doppler effect, anything you hear can shift up or down depending on speed and distance. Add in the different densities of water, temperature of water and salinity levels. All of that changes how sound transmits under water. Then there are thermoclines. Thermocline borders actually block the transmission of sound energy from one thermocline to another. Submarines and ships have towed sonar arrays that can be 'flown' up or down, even left or right (port or starboard). Oh, and anechoic tiles on submarines are like stealth plane design. The absorb sound energy. Hull design could affect sound propagation and return, however, sub hulls HAVE to be built in a certain way to survive underwater.
Human generated noise also follows exact repetitive patterns. Biological organisms don't. You can speed up or slow down recordings and see it easier.

I watched this video and found that I feel you hit enough interesting points. Going into depth, aka classified, was really not needed in this video.
The one thing you touched, and may have been deleted that would have been of interest is the frequency waterfall. You showed the birds, crickets, and trains, but you did not touch upon distance. Sounds tend to get absorbed differently. This can be shown in a house. High-frequency sounds tend not to bounce off of walls where low frequencies do. You can show this by playing music in one room and then going to other rooms in the house and notice how the sound gets base-iey. Another is looking at distant objects around your house. On a clear day, they can be seen well. On a humid day, objects will tend to be bluer the further away, i.e., the red light gets absorbed.
Multipath is something that is well known. When watching TV in the 70's you often see a ghost image; your main image would be shifted as the tv radio waves bounce off of tall buildings. Also, your image of a boat having blank zones is known to ham radio operators.
What I am getting at is many of the topics you covered are well known, even though the specific application in a submarine is classified.

@SmarterEveryDay, at 5:43 you show the train sound. (Not to brag, but I called it before I you said train!!!) This is really cool, since I've never seen how a train shows up on a spectrograph like this. So the question for you is, do you know why the train noise started suddenly instead of a gradual increase as the train moved by? I'm sure the train didn't just start up to full speed all of a sudden. I'm guessing you are a mile or two away from this train moving perpendicular to you???

Turns out trains do not emit these frequencies in all directions equally within a certain range of distance. They are much stronger to the left and right of the train, than front and back. A train is a form of a "line array". It was really cool to see this your spectrograph. I've been told the first research on line array behavior was actually trains, rather than for the purpose of modern line array speakers.

List of variables to be considered/calculated during your next successful submarine engagement:
1. Your Lattitude/Longitude
2. Ocean depth (instantaneous at any given moment and average for the area)
3. Depth of any thermocline layers
4. Water temperature of thermocline layers
5. Presence of any strong warm/cold currents and at what depths
6. Presence of any major underwater geological features
7. Presence of large amounts or large sizes of marine life
8. Your current depth
9. Your current heading
10. Your current speed
11. Rates of change for 8, 9 and 10.
12. Range to enemy contact
13. Contact's bearing and bearing rate
14. Rate of change in contact's bearing rate
15. Contact's speed
16. Contact's depth
17. Whether 15 and 16 are changing, and rate of change if so
18. Whether contact has detected you or not based on above data
19. Phase of the moon
20. Colour of enemy captain's underwear

I was a Sonar Technician on a surface ship in the navy in the 90s.
The passive acoustic analysis is really neat stuff. You can pick out individual components running - generators, pumps... you can even tell how many propellers and how many blades the propellers have by listening. The real science is in knowing the meshing rates of turbine reduction gears.

You hypothetically can be making a ton of noise close to another boat and not be heard due to the way sound bends in water. The temperature, salinity and pressure depth of the water all affects how sound bends in water.

Sound propagation in water is fascinating.

Just a note:
The bearing graph only tells you the movement of a ship relative to your position, at least the way its depicted in this. What it does not tell you (And this is probably one of the things the Navy cut out) is the distance to the object. In theory, two contacts doing the same maneuver at different scales could give the same reading on the bearing graph. However, i reckon that the screen in question would be designed in such a way that the louder a contact is, the stronger the reading on the screen would be. Though, this still doesnt tell you much about the distance of the object, as the amount of noise the ship makes would vary from ship to ship, so youd need to know what the contact in question is (For instance, a big cargo hauler going at full speed 5 miles away would probably make significantly more noise than, say, a german Type 212 doing 4 knots under fuel cell power at a 1 mile distance)

In radar there are multiple transmitters with their own antenna (there are other ways to do phased arrays) and firing each transmitter in time to shape the envelope of the emitted signal allows a flat panel of transceiver antennas to effectively move or sweep the signal across a given area without physically moving the antenna array.  There benefits to this I won't go into but it's the basic idea behind AGIS and over the horizon radar.

This video made me think a lot about my time in engineering college and a subject where we learned about different kind of fiber optic cables. Same principles at work here. There you also have the problem, that light can take different paths in the cable, which smears out pulses, making edges of pulses less defined.

Destin,

As a former sonar supervisor, I can say that it is no more complex than most of the other topics you have covered.

When you were drawing your contacts moving across the flowing bearing graph, you left off one important detail. That is "relative" bearing versus "true" bearing. Relative bearing ALWAYS has the bow at 0-degrees and is therefore the most important. You are safe when the contact is A) on the right, drawing right, B) on the left, drawing left or C) on the surface and you are submerged (assuming it is not a trawler pulling a net - then they are in trouble).

To me, passive detection, analysis and ranging is far more interesting than active sonar. Frequencies used and capabilities are the only classified information...not sound through water itself. The US government cannot silence sound (pun intended).

I’m an electrical engineer and I used to work on the Virginia & Los Angeles class submarines to test for electromagnetic interference. I worked in the radio room, the electronic surveillance room, and the control room testing EMI levels on all types of systems on the subs. This is not active sonar where you are emitting a pulse and expecting it back.
